title.value: Genetic correlates of phenotypic heterogeneity in autism
title.justification: The title is clearly presented at the top of the document, indicating the main focus of the research on genetic correlates and phenotypic heterogeneity in autism.
title.quote: Genetic correlates of phenotypic heterogeneity in autism

extractions.description: This paper explores the genetic differences among autistic individuals, investigating the contributions of common and de novo genetic variants to core and associated autism features, developmental disabilities, and sex differences. Using data from large autism cohorts, the study identifies genetic associations with phenotypic heterogeneity in autism and emphasizes the need for deeper phenotypic characterization.

type.justification: The paper involves extensive data collection and analysis from multiple autism cohorts to investigate genetic influences, indicating an empirical study.
type.quote: Here, we address these four questions by combining genetic and phenotypic data from up to 12,893 autistic individuals from four different datasets.

name.justification: The study focuses on genetic correlates and their impact on autism phenotypic heterogeneity, making genetics the primary research field.
name.quote: The substantial phenotypic heterogeneity in autism limits our understanding of its genetic etiology.

name.justification: The paper focuses on genetic studies related to autism, making Autism Research a core subfield.
name.quote: To address this gap, here we investigated genetic differences between autistic individuals ...

name.justification: The study addresses co-occurring developmental disabilities in autistic individuals as part of the genetic analysis, relating to developmental disorders.
name.quote: Furthermore, in autistic individuals without co-occurring intellectual disability (ID), autism PGS are overinherited by autistic females compared to males.

name.justification: The dataset is mentioned as part of the data sources used in factor analysis and other analyses throughout the paper.
name.quote: combined two widely used parent-reported measures of autistic traits ... for 24,420 autistic individuals from the Simons Simplex Collection (SSC) and the Simons Foundation Powering Autism Research for Knowledge (SPARK) cohorts.

name.justification: The AGRE dataset is utilized in the genetic analysis conducted in the paper.
name.quote: We conducted analyses using data from four cohorts of autistic individuals: the SSC, the Autism Genetic Resource Exchange (AGRE, CHOP sample).
